title: About
text: I am a postdoctoral associate at the the University of Minnesota, Twin Cities. My research integrates microbial ecology, molecular and computational biology, experimental evolution, and field studies to understand the roles of bacteria and fungi in biogeochemical processes in forest and soil ecosystems.

title: Irshad Ul Haq, PhD
text: I am a postdoctoral associate at the the University of Minnesota, Twin Cities. My research integrates microbial ecology, molecular and computational biology, experimental evolution, and field studies to understand the roles of bacteria and fungi in biogeochemical processes in forest and soil ecosystems.

title: Research interests
text:
Structure and function of microbial communities in decaying wood and soil
Microbes play an essential role in wood decomposition and regulate biogeochemical processes. and maintain the functioning of soil and forest ecosystems


Fungal wood decay mechanisms in boreal forests
The large carbon stores in boreal forests, primarily in deadwood, are significantly influenced by fungal decomposition mechanisms (white versus brown rot).


Bacterial-fungal interactions in decaying wood and soil
The presence of a wide array of bacteria and fungi in soil and decaying wood can have important effects on biogeochemical processes, including bioremediation, in both natural and managed systems.
